intro: Haplopappus fremontii subsp. typicus, commonly known as the Fremont's pappus, is a flowering plant native to the western United States. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and distinctive bracts. The plant typically grows in arid or semi-arid environments, showcasing adaptations to drought and poor soil conditions. Its leaves are usually narrow and grayish-green, while the flowers are small and yellow, appearing in clusters. The subspecies typicus is distinguished by its reduced pappus and specific geographic distribution.
